review.title: Calibration with Changing Checking Rules and Its Application to Short-Term Trading
review.abstract: We provide a natural learning process in which a financial trader without a risk receives a gain in case when Stock Market is inefficient. In this process, the trader rationally choose his gambles using a prediction made by a randomized calibrated algorithm. Our strategy is based on Dawid's notion of calibration with more general changing checking rules and on some modification of Kakade and Foster's randomized algorithm for computing calibrated forecasts.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: Calibration is an intensively evolving field of research, where several algorithms have been developed to calculate calibrated predictions, and it is attractive to find some practical applications for these results. Using calibrated predictions to construct short-term trading strategies on the stock exchange looks very natural. In this essay, we construct such strategies and conduct numerical experiments.These experiments show a positive return on six major Russian stocks, and on two stocks we achieve a profit, even if transaction costs are subtracted.In order to construct trading strategies, we develop a more general concept of calibration and prove the convergence results for it. We also present some sufficient conditions under which our trading strategies receive a profit.Fig.2 Speculator capitals gambling on an increase of six Russian stocks (excluding transaction costs - on the left figure, with transaction costs 0.01% - on the right figure).
